summary: This document is a compilation of news clips from January 13, 2020, focusing on the fallout from Jeffrey Epstein's connections to MIT and Silicon Valley. It covers a new MIT report on Epstein's donations, questions about Bill Gates's and Reid Hoffman's ties to Epstein, disciplinary actions against MIT professor Seth Lloyd, and a lawsuit by Harvard professor Lawrence Lessig against The New York Times.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the scandal; his donations to MIT and connections to Silicon Valley billionaires are the subject of multiple news reports compiled in this document.

persons.name: Bill Gates
persons.context: Discussed for his ties to Epstein; his $2 million donation to MIT's Media Lab in 2014 is reported to have been potentially directed by Epstein, which Gates denies.

persons.name: Reid Hoffman
persons.role: LinkedIn founder, MIT Media Lab advisory board member
persons.context: Apologized for participating in fundraising activities with Epstein; brought Epstein to a dinner with Silicon Valley figures in 2015 and was consulted on Epstein matters by Joi Ito.

persons.name: Joi Ito
persons.role: Former director of MIT Media Lab
persons.context: Resigned in September 2019 over reports he deliberately concealed donations from Epstein; sought advice from Reid Hoffman regarding Epstein.

persons.name: Seth Lloyd
persons.role: Nam Pyo Suh Professor of Mechanical Engineering and Physics at MIT
persons.context: Placed on paid leave for deliberately failing to report donations from Epstein; received $60,000 from Epstein in 2005/2006 and deposited it into a personal account.

persons.name: Rafael Reif
persons.context: Faced scrutiny over the Epstein case; signed a gift acknowledgment letter involving Epstein in 2012 but reportedly did not know who Epstein was at the time.

persons.name: Lawrence Lessig
persons.context: Suing The New York Times for a story about an essay he wrote regarding Epstein's donations to MIT, claiming the headline and lede were false and defamatory.

persons.name: Alan G. Spoon
persons.context: Commented on the MIT report, finding Epstein's campus visits 'very disturbing' and expressed full confidence in President Reif's leadership.

persons.name: Denis A. Bovin
persons.context: Commented on MIT's visitor policy and suggested drawing a line at allowing Level-3 sex offenders like Epstein on campus.

persons.name: Marvin Minsky
persons.context: Received a $100,000 gift from Epstein in 2002, according to the MIT report.

persons.name: Robert Millard
persons.context: Was reportedly targeted by Joi Ito in 2016 to woo Epstein as a donor; Epstein invited Millard to dinner, but he declined.

persons.name: Israel Ruiz
persons.role: Former executive vice president and treasurer of MIT
persons.context: One of the vice presidents who knew about Epstein's donations and tried to cover them up; had announced he was stepping down.

persons.name: Leon Black
persons.context: Epstein reportedly claimed in 2014 to have arranged donations from him to MIT, but the MIT report found no evidence to support this.

persons.name: Theodore Schleifer
persons.context: Author of the Recode article analyzing the MIT report and the ties between tech billionaires and Epstein.

persons.name: Colleen Flaherty
persons.context: Author of the Inside Higher Ed article on the fallout at MIT following the Epstein report.

persons.name: Harper Neidig
persons.context: Author of The Hill article about Lawrence Lessig's lawsuit against The New York Times.

persons.name: Ronan Farrow
persons.context: Reported that Epstein was credited with securing Bill Gates's $2 million donation to the MIT Media Lab.

connections.description: Epstein reportedly claimed to have arranged a $2 million anonymous donation from Gates to MIT's Media Lab in 2014. Gates denies any business relationship or that Epstein directed the gift.
Hoffman participated in fundraising activities with Epstein, brought him to a 2015 dinner with Silicon Valley figures, and was consulted by Joi Ito on matters involving Epstein.
Ito, as director of the MIT Media Lab, deliberately concealed donations from Epstein and sought his advice on fundraising. Ito resigned over the scandal.
Lloyd received $60,000 from Epstein in 2005/2006 (deposited personally) and later accepted $225,000 in donations from Epstein to MIT, failing to report them.
Ito sought advice from Hoffman, a Media Lab advisory board member, in 2016 about whether to allow Epstein to attend a conference.
Reif signed a standard gift acknowledgment letter for an Epstein donation in 2012, though the report found he did not know who Epstein was at the time.

events.title: Bill Gates's $2M donation to MIT Media Lab
events.description: Bill Gates made a $2 million donation to the MIT Media Lab. Internal MIT records and reporting by Ronan Farrow suggested Epstein 'directed' the gift, which Gates denies.

events.title: Epstein dinner in Palo Alto with tech leaders
events.description: Reid Hoffman brought Jeffrey Epstein to a dinner in Palo Alto attended by people like Mark Zuckerberg, Elon Musk, and Peter Thiel.

events.title: Epstein donations to Seth Lloyd and MIT
events.description: Epstein gave two $50,000 donations in 2012 and $125,000 in 2017 to MIT professor Seth Lloyd, who failed to report them. Epstein's total donations to MIT were $850,000.

events.title: Release of MIT external report on Epstein
events.description: MIT released an external report by law firm Goodwin Procter investigating Epstein's interactions with and donations to MIT. The report found poor judgment but no policy violations, and failed to definitively settle questions about Gates's donation.

events.title: Lawrence Lessig sues New York Times
events.description: Harvard law professor Lawrence Lessig filed a lawsuit against The New York Times, accusing the paper of publishing false and defamatory information in a story about an essay he wrote regarding Epstein's donations to MIT.

events.title: Epstein visits MIT campus
events.description: Epstein visited the MIT campus in July 2013 to meet with Reid Hoffman and others. The report found Epstein had visited campus nine times since 2013.

locations: U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts
keyFacts: An MIT-commissioned external report found Epstein donated a total of $850,000 to MIT, with $525,000 to the Media Lab and $225,000 to professor Seth Lloyd.
MIT professor Seth Lloyd was placed on paid leave for deliberately failing to report donations from Epstein, including $60,000 deposited into his personal bank account.
The MIT report detailed that Epstein visited the MIT campus nine times since 2013, which board members found 'very disturbing.'
Bill Gates's $2 million donation to the MIT Media Lab in 2014 was reportedly credited to Epstein's influence, a claim Gates denies; the MIT report did not definitively resolve the contradiction.
Harvard law professor Lawrence Lessig sued The New York Times over a story about his essay on Epstein's donations, claiming the headline and lede were false 'clickbait.'
